questions.question_body: Who was prophesized to become king of Rome after his head burst into flames?
Which of the following was NOT a member of the First Triumvirate?
Which Novus Homo from Arpinum was elected consul for the first time in 107?
The Roman consuls Claudius Nero and Livius Salinator were victorious over Hannibal's brother Hasdrubal at what battle in 207?
Which of the following battles did NOT take place during the First Punic War?
Which woman was killed by her father to save her from Appius Claudius?
After which battle in Asia did Caesar famously report "veni, vidi, vici" to the Senate?
At what site was the first so-called "Pyrrhic" victory in 280?
Which consul advocated Concordia Ordinum or "Harmony of the Orders" in 63?
The tribune Marcus Octavius assiduously attempted to obstruct whose legislation?
Which Macedonian king was defeated by the Romans at Pydna in 168?
The 5th century leader _____________ was assassinated for proposing laws which would distribute free grain to the poor.
The Romans lost three legionary standards fighting against the Parthians in 53 at what battle?
Which of the following men was NOT consul in 509?
What law of 287 made plebiscita binding upon the whole community of Roman citizens?
The naval engagement at _________ in 256 cleared the way for Regulus' invasion of Africa.
In 88, who marched on Rome to restore his command against Mithridates?
The Romans were forced to pass under the yoke after a defeat at ___________ in 321.
The sacred geese of Juno startled __________ who saved Rome from the Gauls and earned the cognomen Capitolinus.
Who was the general who committed devotio in order to save his army from defeat in 395?
At which games did Flamininus proclaim the "Freedom of Greece" in 196?
What city, sacked by Hannibal in 219, was the casus belli of the Second Punic War?
Which general, known as the "Sword of Rome," sacked Syracuse in 211?
The revolt of Sertorius in Spain ended when he was assassinated by which of his men?
What law gave legal sanction to the Second Triumvirate?
Against which man was the first Senatus Consultum Ultimum directed?
Who was the victor at the battle of Actium in 31?
Which of these generals was victorious at the battle of Magnesia in 189?
Which king drained the salt plains at Ostia and created the fetiales?
What tribune's death precipitated the outbreak of the Social War?
Which of Antony's lieutenants captured Jerusalem from the Parthians in 37 and installed Herod as king?
Where did the Romans defeat an advancing force of Gauls in 225?
The first occurance of prorogatio, or a prolonged imperium, took place in 326 B.C. when ___________ laid seige to Neapolis.
In 78, who revolted against the Sullan restoration government and attempted to march on Rome?
Who bequeathed Bithynia to Rome in 74?
Queen _________ of the Illyrians waged a maritime war with the Romans in the 2nd Century.
In 200 the consul _____________ called for the Comitia Centuriata to declare war on Phillip II.
What tribune did the Senate order Marius to apprehend because of his use of mob violence?
Whose 1st Century slave rebellion ended after 6000 of his followers were crucified on the Via Appia?
Which of the following was NOT a capital of the rebel confederacy during the Social War?
Scipio Africanus defeated Hasdrubal and which Numidian king at the Great Plains in 203?
Who was the victorious general at the battle of Lake Regillus in 496?
Julius Caesar reformed the calendar in 46 with the help of what Alexandrian scholar?
Which general sacked Corinth in 146?
Which city did Pompey capture in 64 to effectively end the last Mithridatic War?
The palace of Tullus Hostilius on the __________ hill was struck by lightning after the king misperformed a ceremony to Jupiter Elicius.
Which of these men was the first plebeian to become censor?
After Octavian marched on Rome in 43, who served as his co-consul?
Where was C. Triarius defeated by Mithridates in 67?
To what province was Cicero exiled in 58?
Hersilia was the Sabine wife of which Roman king?
Who so impressed the Falerii in 394 BC by his handling of a treacherous teacher that they surrendered immediately to Rome?
In 343 BC, with what city did Rome form an alliance?
When it was originally built in 312 BC, what city was the terminus of the Via Appia?
In 263 BC, which Roman commander defeated Hiero II in Sicily?
Whom did Tiberius Sempronius Longus join at the Trebia River in 218 BC against Hannibal?
Which of these was the strongest opponent of Cato's words, "Carthago delenda est"?
Where did the First Servile War of 135-132 BC take place?
In 110 BC, who was the immediate successor to Sp. Postumius Albinus in the war against Jugurtha?
In 68 BC, who defeated a group of pirates by conquering Crete?
What law gave Pompey the Great the command against Mithridates?
Why did M. Antonius have such an enduring hatred of Cicero?

question_options.A: He had humiliated Antony for his involvement in the Clodius Club.
question_options.B: He had favored Octavian in the Civil War.
question_options.C: He ordered the execution of his father during the Catilinarian conspiracy.
question_options.D: He delivered the Philippic orations against him

questions.question_body: In an agreement in 39 BC, who was given Sicily, Sardinia, Corsica, and the southern part of Greece?
Which king of Rome first brought water to Rome via an aqueduct?
During the beginning of the Republic, who destroyed his palatial house so that he would not be compared to L. Tarquinius Superbus?
In 390 BC, under whose leadership did the Gauls become the first hostile people to occupy Rome?
After the death of Alexander the Great, the Asiatic portion of his empire, including Syria, Babylonia, and the Eastern regions fell under whose control?
At what battle in 262 BC did Rome first defeat Carthage?
Who was the immediate successor of Hamilcar Barca after Hamilcar's death in 228 BC?
The phalanx formation was used for the last time against Rome at what battle of 168 BC?
What people did Antiochus IV try to force to accept Greek culture?
Who was indicted on a charge that he had encouraged M. Livius Drusus in his sympathy for the Italian social cause?
What city was the capital of the Italians during the Social War?
In 77 BC, who was in control of Spain?
Crassus planned in 53 to travel along the Euphrates River to what capital of Parthia?
In 45 BC, ironically on March 15, at what battle was Caesar victorious?
Demaratus, the father of the Roman king L. Tarquinius Priscus, originally came from what city?
The battle won at what site ended the hope of L. Tarquinius Superbus' restoration as king of Rome?
In 350 BC, who were the only two peoples who represented dangers to Rome?
After the Roman victory at Sentinum in 295 BC, what tribe took no further part in the Samnite Wars?
What Roman made the first invasion of Africa during the First Carthaginian War?
What city never fell during wars against both Pyrrhus and Rome, but was ceded to Rome as a provision of the peace treaty at the end of the First Punic War?
In 197 BC, after succeeding his father Attalus of Pergamum, who begged Flamininus to order Antiochus out of Asia Minor?
What leader was finally defeated in 148 BC by Q. Caecilius Metellus to end the Fourth Macedonian War?
Which of these men was NOT a supporter of Ti. Sempronius Gracchus during his first tribunate?
Against whom was the Senatus Consultum Ultimum first used?
What city in 125 BC complained about the Gauls to Rome who then sent M. Fulvius Flaccus?
Which of these events in the life of Clodius happened in 62 BC?

question_options.A: He ran for the office of tribunus plebis
question_options.B: He violated the rites of the Bona Dea festival
question_options.D: He was kidnapped by Cilician pirates

questions.question_body: Pompey the Great was murdered in Egypt due to the influence of which minister of Ptolemy XIII?
What consul of 495 BC helped push the plebeians to secede due to his strict enforcement of harsh laws?
The Samnites were able to focus their full attention on Rome after the defeat of what other enemy in 326 BC?
After his victory at Heraclea, what ambassador and friend did Pyrrhus send to negotiate a peace settlement?
After the First Illyrian War, what Greek island did Rome take possession of?
What city reneged on an alliance with Rome after it was weakened by the Gauls in 390 BC before being pacified and defeated by Cincinnatus?
Where did Hannibal retire to for 4 years before he returned to Carthage in 203 BC?
In terms of numbers killed, what was the worst non-Civil War defeat in Roman history?
Who, resenting the small war bonus he was given because of his avarice, tried to block L. Aemilius Paullus' triumph in 167 BC?
What law(s) opened the consulship to the plebeians in 367 BC?
Spartacus made an agreement with Cilician pirates to do which of these?

question_options.B: hinder the advancement of Cn. Pompeius Strabo Magnus

questions.question_body: Caesarian forces under Curio were defeated in 49 BC by Pompeians led by whom?
Which Roman King introduced the use of a census?
Which member of the First Triumvirate defeated Spartacus' forces in Aquilea in 71?
Which Novus Homo and relative of Caesar was elected consul for the first time in 107?
The Sabine who co-­‐ruled with Romulus was
Which of the following battles did NOT take place during the First Punic War?
Who is often refered to as Rome's second founder?
After which battle in Asia did Caesar famously report "veni, vidi, vici" to the Senate?
At what site was the first so-­‐called "Pyrrhic" victory in 280?
Which law of 90 B.C. offered peace to Rome's Italian allies who gave up the war?
What man was the first privatus or private citizen to be granted imperium in Rome?
Which Macedonian king was defeated by the Romans at Pydna in 168?
Which Roman general fell into Hannibal's trap at Lake Trasimene?
Which king of Rome presided over the destruction of Alba Longa?
Which Roman general's corvus gave Rome a tacitcal advantage in the First Punic War?
What law of 287 B.C. made plebiscita binding on the Patrician community?
The naval engagement at _________ in 256 cleared the way for Regulus' invasion of Africa.
In 88, who marched on Rome to restore his command against Mithridates?
In what year did Rome accomplish its final subjugation of the Latin League?
Which Spartan adventurer was influential in Rome's utter defeat at the battle of Tunes in 255?
Where did M. Agrippa win a naval battle for Octavian in 36?
Who proclaimed the "Freedom of Greece" at the Isthmian Games of 196 B.C.?
Which of Rome's first two consuls had his own sons put to death for conspiring against him?
What kind of sacred animals in the temple of Juno once alerted the Romans to an attack by the Gauls?
Which of these Romans was a prominent representative of the optimates during the Social War?
At what battle in 295 did the Romans defeat the Samnites?
What queen opposed Rome in the Illyrian Wars?
Who was the first king of Rome descended from neither Roman nor Sabine ancestry?
Which of the following was NOT an original member of Tiberius Gracchus' land commission?
Once rid of its last king, the infant republic of Rome found itself besieged by which Etruscan king?
Which African king fought against the combined efforts of Marius and Sulla?
Which of the following chieftans was NOT killed by a Roman commander to win the Spolia Opima?
What Lusitanian guerilla commander, defeated by the Romans, is considered to be the first national hero of Portugal?
Carthaginians were also known as Tyrians. This is because Carthage was originally a:
The first Roman to have his imperium extended beyond his term as consul in order to lay siege to Naples in 326 was
Who among the Decemviri abused a Plebeian girl and sped up the process of writing the 12 Tables?
Where was Catiline defeated and killed by M. Petreius in 62?
Which Gallic chieftan sacked Rome in 390?
The revolt of M. Aemilius Lepidus was defeated by ___________ at the Milvian Bridge in 78.
Which tribune became the second victim of a Senatus Consultum Ultimum in 100?
The Roman general who destroyed Corinth in 146 was
Which Roman bravely inspired the Senate to fight on against Carthage even though it meant that he would have to return to the enemy and face certain death?
Which battle ended Caesar's campaigns in Gaul?
What consul's fleet was defeated by pirates near Ostia in 68?
Which Roman admiral defeated Eudamus at Myonesus, the last notable Roman naval victory over a foreign enemy?
Where did Scipio Barbatus receive a crushing defeat at the hands of the Samnites and Gauls in the Third Samnite War?
Which Roman general quelled the slave rebellion led by Eunus and Cleon in Sicily in 132?
Which office was first instituted in 242 to deal with disputes arising with foreign merchants?
How many wives did Pompey the Great have?
Cicero spent part of 58 and 57 in exile in
Which Roman commander was sent with a fleet to Apollonia in 214 B.C. to combat Phillip V in what became known as the First Macedonian War?
What battle of 305 B.C. brought the Second Samnite War to a close?
What Roman king's consort was a nymph named Egeria?
Which town was at one point the capital of the Italians during the Social War?
What country was Julius Caesar planning an invasion of just before his assassination in 44 B.C.?
Which of these men won the spolia opima?
What Roman commander at the Battle of Aegates Islands brought the First Punic War to a close?
Which of the following was NOT a member of the 1st Triumvirate?
In what year did Hannibal finally die (by killing himself)?
At what early battle of the Second Punic War was Scipio (the future) Africanus said to have saved his father's life?
What position did Sulla hold under Marius during the War with Juguratha?
Who led the Roman forces at the Battle of Beneventum in 275 B.C.?
Who saved a trapped Roman army at Mt. Algidus in 458 B.C.?
Which of the following was NOT a wife of Caesar?
What tribe did Coriolanus join after having fought against them for years as a Roman?
The fifth and final succession of the plebs was ended with the passing of what law in 287 B.C.?
What Roman king's name may have originally been Macstarna?

Lake Vadimo was the site of two battles occurring during Rome's conquest of Italy. The second of these two battles occurred just prior to the Pyrrhic War. During what war did the first Battle of Lake Vadimo occur?
Who was the great uncle of Romulus and Remus?
Directly after what battle in 255 B.C., part of a successful rescue mission, was the Roman fleet caught up in a storm off Sicily and nearly wiped out?
What exiled dictator rescued the Romans from their occupation by the Gauls under Brennus?
What battle of the Third Macedonian War saw a Roman victory and the end of the Antigonid line which had begun almost two hundred years before with the death of Alexander the Great?
What guerilla leader in Lusitania led the resistance against Romans from 146-­‐141 B.C. before being betrayed by his agents?
Which of the following was not a date of a battle in the First or Second Punic Wars?
What Roman King established the cult of Diana and the Census?
According to tradition, in what month of 753 B.C. was Rome founded?
In what year did the first gladiatorial games occur?
In what Italian city did the revolt of Spartacus originate in 73 B.C.?
Who commanded the Optimates against Caesar at the Battle of Thapsus in 46 B.C?
What law of 300 B.C. opened the priesthood up to plebeians, and increased the number of pontifices from five to nine?
What plebeian tribune of 462 B.C. pushed for codified law in Rome, paving way for the Twelve Tables?
At what battle were Cator & Pollux said to have helped the Romans?
What battle occurring in 105 B.C. was the worst Roman defeat since Cannae?
Where did Mithridates VI finally die in 63 B.C.?
Who claimed to have seen Romulus ascending to heaven as the god Quirinus?
What Roman commander died at the Baetis River in the Guadalquivir province during the Second Punic War?
Who was elected in the place of Tarqunius Collatinus when he stepped down from the consulship?
Which law of 66 B.C. transferred the command against Mithridates to Pompey?
Who was the fourth king of Rome?
Who was the first Roman king of Etruscan origin?
What Roman general destroyed Carthage in 146 B.C.?
Who won the Battle of Actium in 31 B.C. which led to the establishment of the empire
Where were a contigent of Gauls defeated by the Romans in 225 B.C. between the First and Second Punic wars?
What woman did Tarquinius Superbus marry and with her conspire to assassinate Servius Tullius?
What famous Roman held the consulship alongside Antonius Hybrida in 63 B.C.?
Eunus is to Cleon as Salvius is to _____________
Which of the following was Rome's first province?
What cheiftan of the Helvetii organized a conspiracy against Caesar in Gaul?
Where did Sextus Tarquinius flee after the rape of Lucretia?
What battle ended the Second Punic War?
Who served as consul a record seven times?
Numa Pompilius was taught by—and loved by—which nymph?
In 49, Julius Caesar crossed what river to ignite the Civil War?
Upon his "transfiguration" by lightning, Romulus was deified as which god?
Son of Pompey the Great, this general had control of Sardinia and tried to take over Sicily—to no avail. He was later caught and killed in Asia Minor?
Which battle DOES NOT belong in the 2nd Punic War?
He acted like a half-wit to his uncle, Tarquinius Superbus, but eventually would lead the revolt against him and even become one of Rome's first consuls?
Which victorious general—and friend—of Octavian's was the actual commander of his fleet at Actium?
What king of the Caecenensis did Romulus defeat to receive the first Spolia Opima?
Cassius & Brutus met their end at which battle?
Who was the consul that replaced Collatinus and was eventually considered, "Friend of the people?
Who served as co-consul with Marius in 86?
Cicero would eventually be proscripted (and murdered) by which member of the Second Triumvirate?
Which historian's capture during the 3rd Macedonian War led to his being enslaved and taken back to Rome?
At the siege of which town, did Julius Caesar finally triumph over the Gallic chieftain, Vercingetorix?
While serving as censor, who was the blind builder of the Appian Way?
In 390 BC, when the Celts ransacked Rome, who was their chieftain?
What was Octavian's original cognomen, it became a source of ridicule during the age of the 2nd Triumvirate?
Which Samnite meddix—against the advice of his father—made the Romans pass under the yoke after the battle of Caudine Forks?
Serving as consul with Gellius Publicola in 36, he served under Marc Antony, but refused to fight Octavian, bringing about a truce between the two men?
Briefly fighting with Horatius Cocles at the Sublican Bridge, who would later kill the king of Tusculum at the Battle of Lake Regillus?
Who was this king of Tusculum and leader of the Latin League?
The leader of the Decemvirs tried to seize a tribune's young daughter for his own deviant purposes. What is this tribune's name who would later lead the prosecution against him?
Which Roman dictator was called from his plough to save Rome from the Aequi?
In which city, besieged by Camillus and the Romans, did a teacher try to hand over schoolchildren as hostages?
Elected consul six times, and made dictator twice, he rose to fame fighting Samnites and Celts—especially a large Celt who was momentarily dazzled by a raven?
From 280-275, Rome fought a war against the Greek, Pyrrhus. What was Pyrrhus' kingdom?
Which tyrant of Syracuse hastened the outbreak of the First Punic War?
Which Roman king is credited with building: the fortification on the Janiculum, the Mamertine Prison & the Fossa Quiritum?
The Roman general, Coriolanus, at first subdued, but later defected to which enemy tribe?
Serving as a mercenary, Hannibal died in the employ of this king?
Adopted by the son of Scipio Africanus, this commander successfully conquered Carthage and enslaved 1/10 of its remaining population?
Tiberius Gracchus tried to enact measures to save land for farmers, soldiers & the poor. This law was called the Lex _________?
Which Roman heroine refused to be a hostage to Lars Porsenna and swam across the Tiber, braving arrows and spears alike?
What was the series of wars which Rome waged upon the troublesome king of Pontus?
At a funeral oration for his aunt, Caesar divulged that this aunt was a descendent of which Roman king?
In Cicero's first prominent law case, he prosecuted the governor of which island?
Pompey went to Judea to mediate a conflict between which two would-be kings
The Parthian commander, ___________, routed the forces of Crassus at the Battle of Carrhae in 53?
Rome's fifth king was _____________.
Before the Third Punic War, which senator was renowned for saying "Karthago delenda est?"
The battle between the Horatii and the Curiatii occurred during the reign of which king?
Who led the consipiracy against the Republic during Cicero's year as consul?
What war, in which Sulla made a name for himself, did Rome fight against the king of Numidia?
He was elected dictator to combat Carthage—he advocated avoiding direct confrontation with Hannibal and earned the name, Cuncator?
What battle of 168 brought the 3rd Macedonian War to a close?
Who was the victorious Roman commander at Mylae in 260?
Which formation came about in direct response to Rome losing several engagements in the Second Samnite War?
What battle in the Latin War is associated with Publius Decius Mus' devotio?
Which queen of Illyria caused Rome to declare war on her kindom because she advocated that piracy as a legitimate trade?
Who were elected the first two consuls after the Decemvirs were ousted?
From what Italian tribe did Rome's second king, Numa Pompilius come?
Under which famed lawyer did Cicero, along with his friend Atticus, apprentice?
In 406, Rome began a 10-year long war against which neighboring city?
During the Battle of Vesuvius in 340, which Roman commander executed his own son for refusing to follow orders?
According to Plutarch, who was the first to stab at Caesar on that fateful day in March?
According to some sources, Rome's sixth king, Servius Tullius, was actually an Etruscan mercenary named ______________?
What engineering feat—used first at the Battle of Mylae—aided Rome's navy during the First Punic War?
Who is the mother of Tiberius & Gaius Gracchus?
Where, in 207, did Claudius Nero and Livius Salinator defeat Hasdrubal?
Who was the king of Numidia against whom Rome waged a series of wars from 111-104?
Who was #10's father-in-law who betrayed him to the Romans, sealing Roman victory?
Which king of Rome is credited for settling an entire town—Palitorium—on the Aventine Hill?
What is the name given to the board of commissioners who put forth Rome's Tables?
What tribe's incursion into Sicily hastened the beginning of the First Punic War?
Which of Caesar's trusted lieutenants abandoned him right before crossing the Rubicon so that he could bring warning to Rome?
Who was the Roman general who defeated Perseus at the battle of Pydna in 168?
Who was the Vestal Virgin who let invading Sabines into Rome for mere bracelets—and was summarily trampled by the Sabines as they entered?
After exiling himself, Hannibal aided which Seleucid king in his preparations for war on Rome?
Cincinnatus' son, ___________, was put on trial for murder, absconded on bail, and left his father to pay an exorbitant fine.
What animal is Pyrrhus credited as the first to bring to Italy to fight the Romans?
What Roman commander is known for putting down Spartacus' slave revolt?
Before which battle in 45 B.C. did the omen of a palm shoot sprouting overnight convince Caesar to adopt Octavian as his heir?
The rape of which woman ignited the war against Tarquin the Proud and led to the installation of the Roman Republic?
At the Battle of Silva Arsia, Lucius Junius Brutus simultaneously died while locked in combat with which son of Tarquin the Proud?
During the 2nd Punic War, what Greek scientist/mathematician helped his native Syracuse repulse Roman attacks?
Which law authorized Pompey's command against Mithradates VI?
Who was Romulus' Sabine wife?
In 222, Marcus Claudius Marcellus defeated which Gallic chieftain to receive that last Spolia Opima?
Which of the following DID NOT occur during the course of 63?
Who defeated an advancing army of Boii near Lake Vadimo in 283?
After which battle in 216 B.C. did Hannibal's cavalry commander, Maharbal, remark, "You, Hannibal, know how to gain a victory; you do not know how to use it?"
Clodius Pulcher had a vendetta against Cicero following the orator's use of power in the Catilinarian Conspiracy. Who physically protected Cicero from Pulcher's gang of thugs?
Which king's run-in with the Sibyl of Cumae resulted in obtaining only three of the nine Sibylline Books?
What mythological characters are said to have fought for Rome at the Battle of Lake Regillus?
Caesar's second invasion of Britain was primarily spent subduing which warlord from north of the Thames?
At the end of the 3rd Punic War, which city became the capital of the new Roman province of Africa?
When the Celts invaded Rome in 390, the Romans took shelter in the citadel. They knew to do this because who had heard the honking of Juno's geese?
At what battle of the Third Samnite War did another Publius Decius Mus perform his devotio?
What Carthaginian leader, against Hamilcar's advice, advocated abandonment of the 1st Punic War (he also did the same during the 2nd Punic War!)?
What Consul was granted power under the first senatus consultum ultimum to go after the followers of C. Gracchus in 121?
Who was the offspring of the union between Julius Caesar and Cleopatra?
Which of the following DID NOT happen in 133?

question_options.B: Attalus III gave his kingdom to Rome

questions.question_body: After Cannae, which king of Macedon allied himself with Hannibal, thus igniting the concurrent First Macedonian War?
Of the following, which WAS NOT a tribe whom Camillus was elected dictator to defeat?
At the onset of the 1st Samnite War, what city cleverly forced Rome to protect it from the Samnites by surrending the city entirely to Rome?
What is the name of the bridge upon which Horatius Cocles made his famous stand?
What law of 445 finally allowed patricians and plebeians to intermarry?
Who was the first Plebeian to serve as Censor in 351?
Who was the Gallic chieftain who first defeated, but was ultimately defeated by Caesar at the Battle of Alesia?
Who was the father of #49 who had tried to unite Celts under one banner and was executed by his own tribesmen for trying to fight Caesar?
Who was Octavian's right-hand man throughout his life, the commander of the fleet at Actium?
Who served as co-consul with Caesar in 59?
What country did King Attalus III bequeath to Rome in 133?
What animal did Pyrrhus introduce in a battle against the Romans?
Upon his death, Romulus was worshipped as what god?
Whose incursion into Sicily hastened the 1st Punic War?
At which battle were the forces of Brutus and Cassius effectively defeated?
What religious counselor to Numa Pompilius has been associated with the Greek goddess of childbirth, Eileithyia?
In the mid-5th century, a Roman commission was sent to Greece to study the laws of what Athenian?
What did Publius Claudius Pulcher throw into the sea before losing the battle at Drepana?
What Spartan strategist aided the Carthaginians during the 1st Punic War?
What Mauretanian king betrayed Jugurtha to Sulla?
What Gallic chieftain defeated the Romans around 390?
In 219 Hannibal's siege of what city led to the 2nd Punic War?
What consul proposed the Lex Pompeia which granted citizenship to all free persons living in Cisalpine Gaul south of the Po?
Who was Octavian's first wife?
How many consulships did Marius achieve?
Which king of Rome was supposedly born a slave?
What former governor of Sicily did Cicero successfully prosecute in 70?
What river did Caesar cross with the immortal line, "Alea iacta est?"
After which battle in 168, did Perseus of Macedon flee to Samothrace?
Who served as dictator in 458 and is considered a model of pietas?
Who begged her husband Coriolanus not attack the city of Rome?
What shepherd found and rescued Romulus and Remus?
What set of triples fought for Rome against Alba Longa?
What supposed grandson of Marius was killed by Antony in 44?
What king of Numidia greedily seized most of the Carthaginian coastal colonies around 155?
In 321 who lured a Roman army into a trap at Caudine Forks?
Who received the enormous power created by the Lex Gabinia?
What king of the Veians was killed by Cossus around 426?
Who is credited with building the Mamertine prison?
After the battle of Thapsus, which Roman statesman committed suicide?
Mago was the son of which Barcid general?
Who was the Parthian commander at Carrhae?
Which Roman dictator successfully conquered the Latins in the Battle of Lake Regillus?
Who steadfastly demanded, "Carthago delenda est," at the end of each speech he gave in the Senate?
Who served as consul several times during the early years of the Republic?
Which naval battle effectively ended the 1st Punic War?
Titus Tatius was the king of what people?
What gangplank with grappling hooks was introduced during the 1st Punic War?
According to Plutach, Gaius Fabricius Luscinus was unable to be bribed by what king?
Who held the imperium in Rome, when the king was away from the city?
On which of the seven hills did Romulus build his first settlement at Rome?
What Italian city rebelled against Rome and declared itself for Carthage in 216?
What woman did Antony officially divorce in 32?
Queen Teuta of Illyria encouraged what group of people to defy Rome and kill Roman envoys?
What king of Syracuse was murdered after pledging his loyalty to Carthage?
What consul demanded unconditional surrender from the Aetolians in 191?
What Vestal Virgin allowed the Sabines into Rome and whose name was applied to a notorious place for punishment?
In 217 B.C., who served as Quintus Fabius Maximus' magister equitum?
Before Mettius Fufetius lost his life at the hands of Tullus Hostilius, Hostilius and what preceding king of Alba sent the Curiati triplets against the Romans' Horatii?
What invading tribe is Tarpeia infamous for letting into the city of Rome?
On what day was Caesar assassinated by members of the Senate?

During the 2nd Punic War, Hasdrubal Gisco betrothed his daughter to Massinissa, then Syphax, king of the Masesyli, then she married Massinissa after Syphax' defeat? Who was this famed Carthaginian beauty?
At which battle is Gaius Marius credited with defeating the Teutones?
Julius Caesar had a favorite niece—who was the mother of Octavian. Who was she?
To which Parthian emperor did Surena present Crassus' standard after the battle of Carrhae?
Gaius Marcius (who would become Coriolanus) received an oak-leaf crown for bravery during the Battle of Lake Regillus—who bestowed him with this honor?
Following the "ascension" of Romulus, Numa Pompilius was elected king. From which tribe did he hail?
Over which city's walls is Tiberius Gracchus traditionally credited with being the first Roman to cross over in the 3rd Punic War?
Who was Cincinnatus' dutiful wife?

King Lars Porsena aided an exiled Tarquinius Superbus, was almost assassinated by Mucius Scaevola, and eventually came to ally his kingdom with Rome. However, his city—and tomb—were completely razed to the ground by which Roman general in 89?
Which ally of Cinna and Marius, and a brilliant commander himself, took up arms against the Romans on behalf of the Lusitanians—who called him "the new Hannibal?"
Which of the First Triumvirate's grandsons actually defeated a Macedonian one-on-one in 29 and was eligible to receive spolia opima, but Octavian prohibited the privilege?
What was the fate of the Appius Claudius Crassus, the leader of the Decemvirs who terrorized Rome?
Which goddess' sacred geese were said to miraculously alert the Romans of the infiltrating Celts in 390?
Which war can we associate with the six-time consul, Marcus Valerius Corvus?
Which king of Rome may have been handicapped, as his name means "crooked arm?"
Tarquinius Priscus, though half-Etruscan, he was also half Greek. From which Greek city-state did his father, Demaratus, come to Italy?
What chieftain of the Averni was the only Celtic commander to consistently trouble Caesar—even defeating him at Gergovia?
Who was the Roman senator Pyrrhus tried unsuccessfully to bribe?
Which Scipio defeated Hannibal at the naval battles Eurymedon & Myonessus?
The Parable of the Body was a device used by which respected senator to convince the plebeians to return to Rome, ending their first secession?
Who was Rome's successful naval commander at Mylae, their first naval victory of the First Punic War?
Jugurtha opined that Rome was "a city for sale and doomed to a quick destruction should it find a buyer" while serving under Scipio Aemilanus where?
What battle gave Pyrrhus his famed "Pyrrhic Victory" in 279?
The Senate passed which law that gave Pompey the command against Mithradates VI?
Which Roman was hailed as "The Sword of Rome" during the 2nd Punic War?
Which tribune's persistent vetoing of Tiberius Gracchus' proposals led to him to be forcibly removed—breaking Roman law?
According to Suetonius, Caesar was allied with which other wealthy politician to gain the consulship of 59, which prompted those who feared Caesar to support Bibulus?
Which patrician replaced Collatinus, became a "friend to the people," and was so beloved and poor that Roman citizens donated toward his funeral?
Shortly before The 12 Tables were codified, what is the name of the plebeian tribune who tried to combat the abuses of the patrician class in 462?
Which consul did Marius replace that led to Rome's defeat of Jugurtha?
Which famed hero of the Sublician Bridge has a name that may mean "one-eyed?"
At what battle did Cincinnatus save the Romans and defeat the Aequians?
Rome fought a series of wars against Veii. One Roman family even waged a private war against Veii and were almost annihilated because of it. Which clan was that?
Tarquinius Superbus finally found refuge in the household of the tyrant of Cumae, but was soon after murdered by a slave. Who was this ruler of Cumae?
Which dictator advocated not confronting Hannibal directly, but rather to delay and hinder him whenever possible—even earning the agnomen, Cuncator?
Who was the tyrant of Syrcause who originally hired the Mamertines to help against Carthage and whose successor had to appeal to Pyrrhus of Epirus for help against them?
Cicero shared his year of consulship (63) with which other consul?
At what battle of 340 did Publius Decius Mus perform his devotio?
Who was the Spartan mercenary employed by Carthage during the First Punic War?
Catiline was able to battle the Republic because he rallied which tribe against Rome?
Who was the Senate's first choice to put down the Spartacus' rebellion, but was already engaged in conflicts in Asia Minor?
After driving the Celts from Rome, Camillus gave the Senate an impassioned speech to dissuade them from abandoning Rome and resettling in which city conquered years before?
Which lieutenant of Caesar's betrayed him by riding back to Rome before the crossing of the Rubicon?
Which law passed in 445 allowed the intermarriage between patrician and plebeian?
Under which renowned philosopher and rhetorician did both Cicero and Caesar study while in Greece—perhaps a reason why both were such great orators?
Which patrician conspired to seize Rome's armory and graineries and take control of the government, but his short-lived rebellion was put down by an aged Cincinnatus?
After the Battle of Arausio in 105, this Roman was captured and burned alive in a wicker cage. It is said that he did not betray Rome, nor did he cry out or scream. Who was this valiant legate?
Where do Marc Antony and Octavian defeat Brutus and Cassius in 42?
What law gave Pompey the command against the Mediterranean piracy?
Which temple was built to celebrate the end of Class Struggle between the patricians and plebeians?
Which event led to the Social War?

question_options.B: the passing of the Lex Iulia
question_options.C: the assassination of M. Livius Drusus

questions.question_body: What kingdom did Attalus III bequeath to Rome in 133?
Who massacred 80,000 Romans and Italians in Pontus in 88?
How many total number of Servile Wars was fought between 135-71?
On whom did Carthage declare war in 151?
Who defeated Marcellus during his siege of Syracuse by his creative inventions?
What battle resulted with a Roman surrender during the 2nd Samnite War?
What office was created from the 1st Plebeian Secession?
What is another name for the office of Magister Populi?
Who was co-consul with Cicero in 63?
Where did Marius defeat the Cimbri in 101?
What Roman displayed legendary rectitude and incorruptibility to Pyrrhus?
What office did Appius Claudius hold when he built the Via Appia in 312?
What city did the dictator Camillus capture in 396?
What king is said to have built the Pons Sublicius?
Who actually raised Romulus and Remus to adults?
What king fought Rome from 280-275?
Whom does Octavian deny the right to dedicate the spolia opima in 29?
What Sueban king did Caesar defeat at the Battle of Vosges in 58?
Who created the Acta Diurna, the world's 1st daily newspaper?
Who assassinated Sertorius in 72?
Who restored Ptolemy Auletes to the throne of Egypt in 55?
Whose agrarian law did Caecilus Metellus Numidicus refuse to swear in 100?
Where did Jugurtha receive great stature from Scipio Aemilianus in 133?
What proconsul in Gaul in 120 completed the defeat of the Allobroges?
What Lusitanian commander was successful from 144-139 against Rome?
Who proposed acceptance to the Roman terms for the surrender of Carthage after the Battle of Zama?
What ended the 1st Macedonian War formally in 205?

question_options.C: pact between Philip V and Aetolia
question_options.D: defeat of Hasdrubal at the Metaurus

questions.question_body: What Roman general stayed behind in Spain after Hannibal reached the Alps?
After what victory was Regulus able to invade Carthage in 256?
After what victory was the 1st major Roman fleet constructed?
Who originally hired the Mamertines as mercenaries?
Who sponsored the law in 287 made all plebiscita binding on all citizens?
Whom did Rome intervene to rescue in the 1st Samnite War?
Which law effected the replacement of consuls with military tribunes and allowed plebians to marry patricians?
What was the capital city of Lars Porsenna?
Where did Marc Antony first meet and form an alliance with Cleopatra?
Who led the Parthians when Crassus was killed in 53?
Whom does Caesar install as king in Britain in his invasion of 52?
As Sulla besieged Athens in 87, whom did Sulla order to raise a fleet?
After the death of Marc Antony in 30, who raised all of his children?
What tribe opposed Hannibal's march through the Alps?
Although the Dictator Mamercus was granted a triumph, who claimed the spolia opima?
What Sabine chief in 460 occupied the citadel of the Capitol in Rome?
According to Livy, who succeeded L. Tarquinius Collatinus?
According to Livy, who first explained the deification of Romulus to the people?
According to Livy, what was the 1st act of Romulus as king?

question_options.C: build the Temple of Jupiter Stator

questions.question_body: The First Triumvirate was between three powerful men EXCEPT _____.
The dates of the Third Punic War:
In 133, Tiberius Gracchus was elected _____.
The dates of the Second Punic War:
Gaius Mucius Scaevola tried to kill _____.
Who used to end his speeches with the phrase Carthago delenda est, "Carthage must be destroyed."
In 202, _____ defeated Hannibal.
The Second Triumvirate was between three powerful men EXCEPT _____.
Who was the first Roman to be consul seven times?
In 52, Caesar defeated _____ at Alesia.
In 123, Gaius Gracchus _____.

question_options.B: became a tribune of the plebs

questions.question_body: In 217, Hannibal was successful at the Battle of _____.
In 49, Caesar _____.

question_options.C: was elected consul the third time

questions.question_body: The First Triumvirate was formed in _____.
In 67, Pompey defeated _____.
What decree urged the consuls to protect the state from any harm?
Crassus and Pompey were made joint consuls in _____ .
In 390, Brennus, the Gallic war chief of the Senones, said these proverbial words:
Romulus was called _____ after death.
Sulla did the following EXCEPT _____.

question_options.B: increased the number of Roman provinces to ten
question_options.D: restored the Senate's right to veto legislation passed by the Council of Plebs

questions.question_body: Who marched on Rome, seized the city and, was elected consul in 88?
In _____, Caesar became pontifex maximus.
The flashpoint of the First Punic War was _____.
Who was the victorious general at the Battle of Vercellae?
In 279, Pyrrhus beat the Romans at _____.
The Samnites lived in _____.
The Jugurthine War was fought between _____.

question_options.D: Gaius Marius and Lucius Cornelius Sulla

questions.question_body: When Caesar won the battle of Zela, he sent back a report to Rome:

question_options.A: Dulce et decorum est pro patria mori

questions.question_body: Spartacus with a band of his fellow gladiators, broke out of a training school at _____.
Tarquinius Priscus began work on the _____.
Caesar was killed in Rome on the Ides of March, 44, by all the following EXCEPT _____.
Pompey the Great was initially called "Magnus" by _____.
Gaius Gracchus is known for his _____.
Who had the nickname "Felix"?
Cornelia, the mother of the Gracchi brothers, was the daughter of _____.
The Battle of _____ was the decisive battle between Caesar and Pompey.
Corinth was razed in _____.
Gaius Marius and Cicero have all in common, EXCEPT:

question_options.B: Both entered politics as a novus homo.
question_options.C: Both were sons of equestrian fathers.
question_options.D: Both were elected consul multiple times.

The dates of the Jugurthine War:

What tribune, backed by the nobles, repeatedly vetoed Tiberius Gracchus's legislation?
